Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Numerical Simulation of Neural Current MR Imaging Experiments
Award.AbstractNarration:
This EAGER award funds a theoretical study of a proposed new technology for measuring neural currents within brain tissue. This research project is headed by Professors Lawrence Frank and Terrence Sejnowski at UC San Diego.

The research program funded by this grant concerns new methods of understanding and measuring the electrical processes that occur within the human brain and which signal brain activity. Current techniques involve functional magnetic resonance imaging (FMRI), but these methods only operate indirectly by triggering on the electrical changes that occur in the blood surrounding the brain or within the brain. Such techniques are therefore limited by the fact that blood flow induces a certain fundamental inaccuracy having to do with spatial separation (the distance of blood flowing prior to FMRI detection) as well as a time lag which separates the time of the original electrical activity in the brain and its subsequent impact on the surrounding blood. In this study, by contrast, the PI's will analyze a new technology which might be able to completely overcome these limitations by focusing directly on the neural currents within the brain tissue itself. This new technology is referred to as "neural current MRI", and the PI's will model the effects of these neural currents and the possibilities for their detection by conducting a detailed numerical simulation of such brain activity.

The implications and broader impacts of such a project are significant. The results of such a study might help to pave the way for a whole new technology by which we might be able to image the brain with a precision never previously achieved. Moreover, because the research in this proposal crosses many traditional boundaries (including biology, physics, and computational mathematics), it is highly interdisciplinary. The results of this study therefore have the potential to benefit research in a variety of related disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ability to image human brain activity with functional magnetic resonance imaging  (fMRI) has revolutionized our understanding of how the brain works.   However, one major drawback is that this technique cannot directly measure the electrical activity of the brain. Instead, it relies on measuring signal variations generated by the changing magnetic state of blood flow near activated regions.  These changes occur on a time scale much slower than actual electrical activity, and are not directly localized to the activity itself. Neural current MRI (ncMRI) is a promising new neuroscientific method that allows the direct measurement of magnetic field variations caused by  localized electrical activity, and has the potential to revolutionize the field of neuroimaging by providing much greater spatial and temporal resolution of brain activity than previously possible.  However, because magnetic fields generated by neural electrical currents are extremely small, all attempts to develop a robust ncMRI method have so far been unsuccessful. This is in large part due to the difficulty in characterizing the complex interplay of neural current field distributions in tissues with the complicated sequence of spatially encoding magnetic fields used during MRI scanning. 

The goal of this NSF-funded project was to develop a computational platform to simulate the entire ncMRI process, from modeling the generation of electromagnetic fields in brain tissue models, to their influence and eventual detection in an idealized MRI scan optimized for resolving these signals, to an experimental platform for validating these findings in a more “real world” MRI scanning environment.  This project had four major goals: 1) Develop a pipeline to convert neuroanatomical and neurophysiological data into a computational model; 2) Incorporate these models into a computational platform for the numerical simulation of the MRI signal changes generated by the magnetic field induced by neural currents and the diffusion of water within the tissue; 3) Design and construct an MRI phantom with controllable currents and an equivalent computational model; and 4) Develop mathematical tools for characterizing diffusion statistics from experimental data capable of detecting the subtle changes due to neural currents.  The major outcomes of this project are as follows:


1. We have developed a computation platform, called DiffSim, that generates idealized neural tissue geometries and physiological properties needed for assessing the influence of key parameters, such as current density, neural geometry, and tissue permeability in actual tissue.  It can also input more complex geometrical models. The platform is built upon an easy to use and intuitive graphical user interface (GUI) that allows the user to easily manipulate the physiological parameters of the system as well as MRI acquisition parameters. This means we can efficiently test a wide range of experimental scenarios without having to perform a huge number of complex and expensive MRI experiments.

2. At the heart of the DiffSim platform is the numerical simulator that performs a Monte Carlo simulation of water diffusion in arbitrary geometries. It generates an MRI signal based upon specified MRI acquisition inputs, and then pipes this signal through any user- specified analysis routines. DiffSim also incorporates magnetic fields induced by current densities computed using NEURON software. The magnetic fields produce a change in diffusion-weighted MRI signal magnitude and phase relative to the case of no neuronal currents.
